text:
Christchurch Adventure Park committed to Christchurch after extensive fire damage MICHAEL HAYWARD Last updated 18:21, February 17 2017 Fairfax NZ 
Port Hills fire damage from the air. 
Extensive fire damage to the trees in Christchurch Adventure Park (CAP) hasn't destroyed the team's desire to rebuild. 
CAP spokeswoman Anne Newman said the park was "committed to Christchurch" but it was too early to tell when it would reopen. 
"We haven't been able to get into the park to properly assess the damage. We know the village and the base station haven't been touched by fire," Newman said. DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
An aerial photo of Christchurch Adventure Park shows the destruction caused by the fires. 
"Until we can assess, there's very little else that we can say at this stage." 
READ MORE: * 100 jobs at Christchurch Adventure Park 
Aerial photos show extensive fire damage to the slopes of the park, with trails cutting a vivid line through the scorched earth. However, the chairlift cable has been running throughout the ordeal of the fire, in order to prevent hotspots, and is still operating. 1 NEWS 
Choppers with monsoon buckets continue to swoop over fire smouldering on the Port Hills. 
Newman said the team were "definitely committed to the park", which opened in December after an eight month, $20 million dollar build, and were committed to honouring the contracts of about 100 staff they employed. 
"We've got contracts in place with staff and we'll be looking to get them involved in the clean up process where they can." 
The park was closed until further notice and measures would be put in place to monitor people trying to get into the grounds once the fires were out. MICHAEL HAYWARD/FAIRFAX NZ 
An abandoned digger is wreathed in smoke on the ridge above the adventure park on Wednesday. 
Newman said support from the public had been brilliant and really helped the team. The park had been inundated with offers of help from the public but it was too early to take anyone up yet. 
"We're really grateful for the support but until we know what we're dealing with, it's difficult to be able to take any further action." 
norrissphotography.co.nz 
Timelapse of the Port Hills fire 
The land is owned by forestry company McVicar Timber Group, which has leased CAP the land for 50 years. Newman said CAP would work with the landowner on their way forward. 
"We're really thinking of our neighbours ... because a lot of them lost their homes or have been evacuated from their homes," Newman said. IAIN MCGREGOR 
Helicopters have been part of a concentrated effort to protect the village and base station of the adventure park. ALDEN WILLIAMS/FAIRFAX NZ 
The multi-million dollar Christchurch Adventure Park opened in December last year. - Stuff
